CONCLUSION: Remainder inadmissible;Violation of Article 6 - Right to a fair trial (Article 6 - Civil proceedings;Article 6-1 - Fair hearing;Adversarial trial;Public hearing);No violation of Article 34 - Individual applications (Article 34 - Hinder the exercise of the right of petition);Non-pecuniary damage - award
JUDGES: Anatoly Kovler;André Potocki;Angelika Nußberger;Ann Power-Forde;Dean Spielmann;Karel Jungwiert
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicants , who are a couple , were born in DATE and DATE respectively . The second applicant died in DATE . The first applicant lives in GPE , LOC .

CARDINAL . The applicants , both wheelchair - bound and having firstdegree disability status , repeatedly requested social - security services to provide them with a car adapted to their disability . Their numerous complaints in this respect to ORG , Members of ORG , and Administration of the President of GPE proved unsuccessful . As it was mentioned in the authorities’ letters to the applicants , according to the medical expert report ordered by the social - security services , the first applicant was not entitled to a free car and driving was contra - indicated in respect of the second applicant .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicants , apparently assisted by counsel , lodged a claim against ORG challenging the refusal to provide them with a car and claiming compensation for non - pecuniary damage .
CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG of GPE ( “ the district court ” ) fixed the hearing for DATE and at some point , apparently on the same date , summoned the applicants to appear at the hearing .

CARDINAL . According to the ORG , on DATE one of the applicants received the respective notification . They submitted a copy of an acknowledgment - of - receipt card containing information on the date and time of the hearing , the name of the court , the date of notification , and signatures of a recipient and a postman .
CARDINAL . According to the applicants , they did not receive the summons .

CARDINAL . On DATE the district court , having heard the defendant ’s representatives , rejected their claim because the applicants had lodged it against a wrong defendant . The court established that the social welfare services did not belong to ORG and that the latter did not have power to review their decisions . The applicants were absent from the hearing . The court found , with reference to the acknowledgment - of - receipt card , that they had been duly summoned and examined the case in their absence . The representative of the respondent authority was present .
CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG representative received a copy of the judgment of DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicants appealed against the judgment . They complained , inter alia , that their right to a fair trial had been violated as neither they nor their lawyer had had a chance to attend the hearing due to their having been summoned belatedly .
CARDINAL . On DATE the district court on the ORG request extended the time - limit for lodging the grounds of appeal .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG adjourned the examination of the applicants’ appeal until DATE , having found that the parties had not been notified of the date of the hearing in a timely manner .

CARDINAL . According to the Government , at some point the district court dispatched summonses to the parties , including the applicants , informing them of the date and time of the appeal hearing . According to the applicants , neither they nor their representative received the summons .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG upheld the judgment of DATE on appeal . The court examined the case in the applicants’ absence , having mentioned that they had been notified of the appeal hearing . As regards the ORG complaint about their absence from the hearing at the first instance court , the appeal court found that they had been properly summoned . The court further upheld the lower court ’s finding that the civil action was lodged against the wrong defendant .
CARDINAL . On DATE the application was communicated to the Government .
CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG requested the case file from the district court in order to prepare ’s observations on the admissibility and merits of the application .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG received the case file .

CARDINAL . On DATE Ms Stakhiyeva , the first applicant ’s representative before the ORG , requested the district court to grant her access to the case file concerning the applicants’ civil proceedings .
CARDINAL . On DATE the registry of the district court rejected her request having advised her that she could be granted access to the file not DATE following the request .

CARDINAL . On DATE the President of the district court refused to examine the representative ’s oral complaint in this respect , apparently having provided no reasons for the decision . It appears that on the same date the lawyer lodged a written complaint about the refusal to allow her to study the file , but the petition remained unanswered .

CARDINAL . On DATE the registry of the district court again rejected the applicant ’s new request for access to the file , and on the same date the President of the district court disallowed her complaint in this respect .
CARDINAL . On DATE the registry of ORG returned the case file to the district court .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG advised the ORG that the file had been transferred to the district court and was available for study . On DATE this letter was forwarded by the ORG to the applicant ’s representatives .
CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG received the ORG ’s observations and on DATE forwarded them to the applicant ’s representatives with a request to provide observations in reply .

CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE the applicant ’s lawyer requested to grant her access to the case file . She submits that on DATE the registry disallowed her request , and the President of the court refused to discuss the matter with her .
CARDINAL . On DATE she was advised by the registry of the district court that the file was available at the registry .
CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE the lawyer studied the case file .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant ’s lawyers submitted the observations in reply to the ORG ’s observations on the applicants’ case .
